content.title: Goal
content.text: A Sitemap is a hierarchical diagram showing the structure of an application. They ensure content is in a logical place that users would expect to find it and can be used as a reference point for wireframes and user flows.

content.title: Benefits
list: Show how the navigation should be structured
Help identify where content fits and what needs to be produced
Clearly display the relationship between different pages

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Personas
Journey Mapping
Event Storming
Story Mapping

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather data from previous mapping activities. Ideally a lot of the work will already be done!
If details are missing run a card sort session, writing down all page names on cards and sort them into categories
From all gathered information create an initial mindmap with a hierarchical view of all pages
Review this diagram against documented User Journeys to ensure the taxonomy support them
Review whether all personas understand the labelling you have come up with
Review if there are any categories that are too large or small and break them up where necessary
Pages can then be ordered in terms of user interaction order to produce a Site Flow diagram if not too complex

content.title: Deliverables
list: A Sitemap diagram that demonstrates the navigation layout and organisation of content
A Site Flow diagram, showing roughly the order of user interaction for each page in a category

content.title: Goal
content.text: A User Flow is a sequence of steps the user needs to take in order to accomplish a task inside the application. Visualising these sequences helps to improve and simplify an existing process, or design an optimised flow and determine what information is required. ?It also helps to eliminate guesswork and ambiguity for the developer.

content.title: Benefits
list: Helps to determine if the current process is complete or if steps are missing
Discover if the design can be simplified and whether the number of steps reduced
Determine if each next step is obvious enough, or if further information is required
Provides documentation for all user interactions

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping
Event Storming
Sitemap Diagram

content.title: The Process
ordered: First list out all entry points into the application and possible landing pages
For each persona create user flows using only text
Each step should state what the user sees and what they do to progress to the next step
Start with happy paths, then move onto edge cases and error paths
From these flows draw sketches representing the UI so that each step can be more easily visualised
Once confirmed these sketches can be digitised

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of diagrams documenting all user interactions with the application

content.title: Goal
content.text: Wireframing is a way to design an application interface at the structural level. A wireframe is commonly used to lay out content and functionality on a page based on the previously defined User Flows. Wireframes help establish the basic structure of a page before visual design and content is added. Wireflows are used to show the relationship or flow between pages, while Interaction (IX) Flows define each interactive element’s trigger, feedback, rules, and loops/modes.

content.title: Benefits
list: Conveys the overall direction and description of the user interface
A quick way to review and amend the structure of key pages based on user and business needs
Great way of getting feedback from users and stakeholders
IX Flows centralise the flow, visual design, and interactions in one document
Reduces guesswork and ambiguity on the developer’s part

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Event Storming
User Flows
Sitemap Diagram

content.title: The Process
ordered: Based on the previously defined User Flows, mock up a wireframes for every page containing the key elements required by users to complete those flows
Consider usability conventions, spacing and information hierarchy while designing wireframes

Once wireframes have been completed Wireflows can be created by connecting each wireframe together with arrows to display user interactions and how their workflow causes them to navigate between pages
Once all Wireflows have been completed a single Interaction flow can be produced

Create a reference panel that defines the types of gestures and their representative symbols, definitions for terms used when describing interactions and a legend that defines the flow lines and other symbols
Insert your wireframes with enough space for arrows and containers to fit around them

For each wireframe interactive element add a reference box listing: the name and trigger with the matching icon, what feedback the user receives, what rules there are for what can and cannot be done and any different modes the element supports
Connect wireframes with lines for connections between screens

content.title: Deliverables
list: A series of individual wireframes for each core page of the application
A series of Wireflows documenting the interactions between wireframes
A single Interaction Flow documenting each interactive element’s trigger, feedback, rules, and loops/modes

content.title: Goal
content.text: Style Tiles consist of fonts, colors and interface elements that communicate the essence of a visual brand. They help form a common visual language between the designers and the stakeholders and provide a catalyst for discussions around the preferences and goals of the client.

content.title: Benefits
list: Help to nail down a specific aesthetic
Establish a direct connection with actual interface elements without defining layout
Help translate established brands smoothly to an interface
Quick to produce without the need to create an entire style guide

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Stakeholder Interviews
Event Storming

content.title: The Process
ordered: Research any existing company branding
Have a design kickoff meeting involving stakeholders to get design ideas
Interpret how the adjectives and themes discovered translate into design principles, such as balance and emphasis
Determine themes from the aggregated adjectives and begin to match them up with styles
Present multiple tiles and gather feedback for production of a new set of times
Continue creating refined style tiles until an accepted core design language is agreed upon

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of potential style tiles
An agreed style tile that defines the core design language going forwards

content.title: Goal
content.text: Design Systems encompass Style Guides (that define abstract styles) and Pattern Libraries (that define usable blocks) and also focus on defining rules and connections of an application. The goal is to create an asset that will stand the test of time, is open for additions and is accessible for anyone new to dive right into the guide with ease. In some cases a full Design System is required, in other cases a basic Style Guide will do.

content.title: Benefits
list: Record all design elements and interactions that occur within the application
List crucial UI components such as buttons, typography, color and navigation menus
Document important UX components like hover states, dropdown fills and animations
Contain live elements and code snippets for developers to reference and use

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Style Tile Design

content.title: The Process
ordered: Create an existing UI inventory, including patterns, colors, typography, icons and spacing layouts
Review the state of the existing inventory to discover inconsistencies, UX problems or issues negatively affecting the software development process
Discuss with stakeholders the need for either a Style Guide, Pattern Library or Design System to eliminate raised issues
Determine the technologies being used for the application and agree the best tools to use going forward
If creating a Style Guide define the color palette, typography, icons and page structuring
If creating a Pattern Library define reusable components, such as buttons, notifications, tables and forms
If creating a Design System define the application rules and connections including motion, accessibility and taxonomies
All these documents should be living and are not expected to cover all possibilities going forward. If new features are required later in development the Design System can be updated

content.title: Deliverables
list: A defined Style Guide defining abstract styles
A defined Pattern Library defining usable blocks
A defined Design System defining rules and connections

content.title: Goal
content.text: High Fidelity Mockups are more complete representations of the application interface than Wireframes. The previously created Design System can be used to drag in elements and quickly produce an interface the very closely resembles the finished product. These mockups can even be made clickable and respond to the user’s actions, mimicking authentic interface interaction.

content.title: Benefits
list: Provides a clear idea as to how the interface will look and work
Perfect for testing and gaining accurate feedback from the client
Less likely to have errors when testing than a coded prototype

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Wireframes & IX Flows
Design Systems

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather previously designed wireframes and have the Design System at hand
For each wireframe update the content following the Style Guide and using the components documented in the Design System
Decide on software that mimics user interaction and connect the new High Fidelity Mockups using the defined IX Flows

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of High Fidelity Mockups for each previously produced Wireframe using the Design System
A interactive demo with simulated clickable links between pages
